CricketMatch.MatchReport:
Extraordinary game .... that I missed!

Until I get the full report, have a look here

In case things vanish from that website, here is a copy. Copyright acknowledged appropriately ...

2 bowlers, 6 balls and 2 hat-tricks Cricketers in Twyford are investigating whether their players have performed a cricketing first with two hat-tricks by two bowlers in the same game.

The extraordinary feat happened in an away fixture against Binfield, during which paceman Tim Cooper and veteran spinner Tom Fort both got three batsmen out in three consecutive balls.

Twyford and Ruscombe Cricket Club has a large number of players who have been playing village cricket for more than 25 years and no-one can recall ever seeing a double hat-trick before.

Mr Cooper, who is in his first full season for the club, ripped through Binfield's top order batsmen, taking the wickets of both openers and the number four batsmen.

Wicket-keeper Adam Smith described the three balls as "a terrible shot, a good catch and a good old-fashioned straight ball".

After taking his third wicket, Mr Cooper was heard to say: "I don't really care what happens now.

"I've taken a hat-trick."

Mr Fort, who has scored more than 10,000 runs for the club and is in his 33rd season, took the tail-end of the batting order apart.

He said: "I'm thrilled. I've taken one hat-trick before but that was when I was a quick bowler more than 30 years ago when I got the figures of six wickets for one run, but wickets were more helpful back then.

"I didn't think it would happen again. When I got two in a row I just concentrated on bowling a straight ball and the batsmen missed it.

"I've seen batsmen running seven in one go, one-handed catches on the boundary, dreadful umpiring decisions, comical run-outs and people being sick in the bushes while fielding, but I've never seen anything like this and doubt I will again."

The club is now set to consult Wisden Cricket Monthly magazine to try to find out if a double hat-trick has ever been done before.

Twyford won the match comfortably with five wickets to spare, with batsman Ken Cochrane smashing 75 not out, as the club comfortably reached the target of 121.

The club is always looking for new talent. For more information visit the website www.twyfordcc.org.uk.
